Issues.Title: null checks on !default variables are useless because they can't be null
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**.

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **version** [0.9.3]
This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description

Consider this code from Bulma's SASS source: https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/e5ee280b32c2bac94e363013777ff41d1a9ed2dc/sass/helpers/spacing.sass#L9-L31

`$spacing-horizontal` and `$spacing-vertical` have `!default` to make the customizable.
From the SASS documentation:
> To make this possible, Sass provides the !default flag. This assigns a value to a variable only if that variable isn‚Äôt defined or its value is [null](https://sass-lang.com/documentation/values/null). Otherwise, the existing value will be used.

This means that both of these variables can **never be** null. If they get set to null outside, `!default` kicks in and overwrites that value.
This means not only that the null checks are useless, but also that the generation of these classes can't be turned off, which was probably intended.
I found this tweet which claims that an empty list / array works instead, but it creates an error when i try to compile it because at least in the current versions of SASS, an empty list is not equal to null: https://twitter.com/TweetsOfSumit/status/1346502700893155328?s=20&t=ZSeM19qMCyagy71ppkyNpw
And even if that was true, it's not documented anywhere.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "null checks on !default variables are useless because they can't be null" (#3507)

Issues.Title: jQuery cannot toggle 'is-hidden' elements
Issues.Body:
### Overview of the problem Bug This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.3/bulma.min.css My **browser** is: Chrome, Edge, Firefox I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? Yes (I searched "is-hidden" and "jquery") ### Description When using 'is-hidden' on an HTML element, then the element is hidden (as expected) but cannot be shown again using jQuery's toggle() function. The reason is that is-hidden uses "!important" ("display: none !important;") which jQuery don't like when classes are used. * Chrome: Fails * Edge: Fails * FF: Fails ### Suggested solution Remove the "!important" part from the `is-hidden` class. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Create HTML document with below code 2. Click "Toggle" button ### Expected behavior The hidden text "Hello world" is shown. ### Actual behavior The hidden text "Hello world" is *not* shown. Works when I remove the "!important" part from "display: none !important;". (Consider also what other issues this change might lead to; it might not be worth fixing.) ### Workaround Toggle() works when replacing `is-hidden` with: ```html

Hello world

``` ### HTML to reproduce ```html Toggle demo

Hello world

```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "jQuery cannot toggle 'is-hidden' elements" (#3499)

Issues.Title: Unify the look of the tabs of the Panel and the Tabs components
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->

My **browser** is: Google Chrome
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description

<!-- Description of the bug, enhancement, or question -->

The tabs of the `Tabs` component and the tabs of the `Panel` component do not have the same look, especially regarding the hover state, and the tabs of the `Panel` component do not allow the `is-left` and `is-right` classes.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Look at the hover state on the [`Panel`](https://bulma.io/documentation/components/panel/) component
2. Look at the hover state on the [`Tabs`](https://bulma.io/documentation/components/tabs/) component
3. Try to use the `panel-tabs is-left` or `panel-tabs is-right` class when using the `Panel`
 
### Expected behavior

<!-- What you expected to happen -->
- When hovering a tab in a `Panel`, the bottom border should react the same way it would in a `Tabs` component
- When using `panel-tabs is-left`, the tabs should be justified on the left
- When using `panel-tabs is-right`, the tabs should be justified on the right

### Actual behavior

<!-- What actually happened -->
- When hovering a tab in a `Panel`, the bottom border does not react
- When using `panel-tabs is-left`, the tabs are still centered
- When using `panel-tabs is-right`, the tabs are still centered

![Hover state in `Panel`](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47030586/156405463-58f07863-2712-4edc-a7e1-b2fe99b143e7.png)
![Hover state in `Tabs`](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47030586/156405657-47357160-63a6-4e0c-a813-568adbaaef8f.png)

Issues.Title: Customisation of $size-x and spacing helpers with the same initial values
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
This is probably a feature request.
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.3
My **browser** is: Firefox 97.0 (64-bit)
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**

### Description

<!-- Description of the bug, enhancement, or question -->

Use `$size-x` for spacing values where they overlap.

https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/0.9.3/sass/helpers/spacing.sass#L11
```sass
$spacing-values: ("0": 0, "1": 0.25rem, "2": 0.5rem, "3": $size-7, "4": $size-6, "5": $size-4, "6": $size-1, "auto": auto) !default
```

Are the sizes intentionally not used for this? I don't see a reason not to keep sizes uniform across everything, with certain contexts using different sizes in different places. I am aware that `$size-x` variables are mentioned as typography.

This is probably a breaking change, in which case `$root-size-x` or something could be added which both `$size-x` and `$spacing-values` would reference.
```
$root-size-x
|
+-- $size-x
|   |
|   +-- $sizes
|
+-- $spacing-x
    |
    +-- $spacing-values
```
One can then either customise both size types at once, using `$root-size-4: 1.6rem`, or either typography and spacing sizes separately. In either case, adding additional `$spacing-x` variables to customise specific spacing values makes sense to me.

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--
1. First Step
2. Second Step
3. and so on...
-->

1. Customise `$size-4`
2. Add the `m-5` class (or really any spacing-5) to an element

### Expected behavior

<!-- What you expected to happen -->

Setting `$size-4: 1.6rem` should modify both the relevant font size and spacing.

### Actual behavior

<!-- What actually happened -->

Issues.Title: CSS logical properties for better RTL support
Issues.Body:
This is a **new feature with improvements and bug fixes**.

Support for CSS logical properties to provide better support for RTL websites.

This PR also fixes the following issues

- #2347 Better nomenclature for css modifiers with `is-end` instead of `is-right`
- #3437 Fix Border radius on RTL
- #3426 Fix loading spinner on `input` and `select`
- #3419 Fix RTL `is-right` by providing `is-end`
- #3409 Fix RTL `is-right` by providing `is-end`

### Proposed solution

Use of CSS logical properties such as `inset-inline-start` instead of `left` [read more here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Logical_Properties). This solves a lot of the issues with the RTL support and simplifies the development of The Bulma CSS framework.

### Tradeoffs

- A Learning curve for logical properties and the bundle size increased by `10 KB`
- [Can I Use CSS Logical Properties](https://caniuse.com/css-logical-props) shows `84.64%` full support and `13.1%` with partial support.

### Testing Done

Yes, testing was done by testing the documentation after generating a new bundle for it that uses this version.

### Changelog updated?

Yes

Issues.Title: Navbar burger doesn't expand to full height and is off-center when navbar is higher than usual
Issues.Body:
This is about a bug in **Bulma**. ### Overview of the problem This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** I'm using Bulma **version** bulma@~0.9.3 My **browser** is: Safari 15.3, but same happens in Firefox I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate** - I used search and didn't find any match for burger ### Description ### Steps to Reproduce [CodePen](https://codepen.io/svkurowski/pen/podyYyO) Basically: ```
Aktenkoffer
Home Documentation
More
About Jobs Contact
Report an issue
Sign up Log in
``` ```css @import "https://pro.fontawesome.com/releases/v5.2.0/css/all.css"; @import "https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bulma@0.9.3/css/bulma.min.css"; ``` (note the `is-size-4` on the brand label) Then reduce window width until Navbar burger appears. ### Expected behavior Burger fills full height of the Navbar, and icon is centered. ### Actual behavior Burger is positioned in the top, and doesn't fill the height (seen when hovering), and is not centered. The issue is that the burgers `height` is hardcoded to `3.25 rem`. ![Screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2794645/152810854-3d6c8926-5458-4a70-821d-6dc719c593cd.png) ### Workaround ``` .navbar.is-info .navbar-burger { height: 4rem; } ``` I might try fixing this myself when I find some time.

Issues.Title: Incorrect behaviour of 'nav-right' for Bulma version above 0.5.3
Issues.Body:
When using Bulma version 0.5.x and previous versions, the behavior of `nav-right` is consistently correct. `nav-left` position the `nav-item` to the left `nav-right` position the `nav-item` to the right But when using Bulma version 0.6.x and later versions, the behavior of `nav-right` is incorrect. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Create a stylesheet definition: ``` ``` 2. Create `nav-menu` and `nav-item` ```
Home Right About Us RIght Contact Right
Home Left About Us Left Contact Left
``` 3. The behavior is correct for both `nav-right` and `nav-left`; 4. Change the stylesheet definition in step 1 from version `0.5.3` to version `0.6.0` » ... » `0.9.3`; 5. Then we got that the behavior for `nav-left` is correct but the behavior for `nav-right`is incorrect. ### Expected behavior `nav-right` should consistently position `nav-item` to the right ### Actual behavior `nav-right` incorrectly position `nav-item` to the left
